rComments: Serves its purpose well as an introductory course by functioning as a discussion of topics, saving the depth for later classes. Grading for Amena's class was based off daily reading quizzes and two sets of essay questions (four each), counting for 20% and 80% of your marks respectively. Would advise against if you despise off-topic conversations.

As an engineering major I'd have to say I enjoyed this class a lot. While most people fell asleep, her lectures are easy to understand and the only work is notes, group videos, and a paper? Put some effort and time and you will pass with flying colors.
Very natural lecturer. One gets the feeling that she enjoys what she is doing, and truly enjoys helping people. Very personable. And knows the subject well. Very intelligent.

The required readings chosen were good but were not explained sufficiently. I ended up not learning anything and just read a bunch of text that was given no explanation. Everyone just stated their own useless opinions and I never got an understanding of the material.

Class assignments were fair. There is no structure to the class. Everyone just says their opinion, you do not learn much. I understand that a philosophy class should express personal beliefs but it should not overrun the class. The purpose should just be exploring and analyzing certain material.  Overall, I did not learn anything worth learning.

Very interesting class! The book (Does the Center Hold) was probably the best in-class text I have used. Lectures were discussion-oriented and elaborated on readings. Tough to endure during summer (3hr class), but definitely worth it in my opinion.
